title: About Me
text:
A short list of what I love to do.







Water Polo
From a young age, I tried many different sports, including baseball, basketball, and tennis, but didn’t find a meaningful connection with any of them. It was then that I found water polo, a unique mix of endurance, skill, and teamwork. I was instantly hooked, begging my mom to play on the local club team. This was over 10 years ago, since then I have played for my local high school, community college, and now the UCSB club team.


Traveling
Fortunately, I have been able to travel to many incredible places, taking in their landscapes and learning about their unique cultures. My personal favorite locations have been Italy, Switzerland, Germany, and Hawaii. I hope to keep exploring in the near future and learn more about environmental opportunities in unfamiliar places.


Surfing
Growing up near the ocean, I remember always loving the beach and going in the water. This naturally progressed into learning to surf, my personal favorite way to connect with nature. I not only love the aspect of reading the waves and expressing myself through my surfing, but I love to just sit out in the water and take in each beautiful day. I am also very interested in surfboard shaping and design, hopefully making my first in the near future.









Ventura college water polo







Monteacuto delle Alpi, Italy







Ventura point

title: Scott Wagner
text: Hello! My name is Scott Wagner. I am currently a third year Environmental Studies major at UCSB. Outside of class I love to surf, climb, hike, camp, and play water polo. Look around my website to learn more!

title: Creating a Figure in RStudio
text: Figure created using RStudio in order to display differences in Tussock height (cm) measured between sites (burned and unburned). Site variables are differentiated by color, burned (green) and unburned (blue), with mean and standard error overlayed.

title: Creating a Figure in RStudio
text: Figure created using RStudio in order to display differences in Tussock height (cm) measured between sites (burned and unburned). Site variables are differentiated by color, burned (green) and unburned (blue), with mean and standard error overlayed.

title: Creating a Figure in RStudio
text:
Code and Output

#Read in packages
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(readr)
library(flextable)
library(dplyr)
library(effectsize)
library(ggplot2)


tussocks <- read_csv("2016ARFTussockHeight.csv")

tussocks_clean <- 
  read.csv("2016ARFTussockHeight.csv") %>% # Loads the data
  clean_names() %>% # Cleans column names
  mutate(site = recode(site, # Recodes site values
                       "Sev" = "Burned",
                       "Unb" = "Unburned"))

# Color for each site
site_colors <- c("Burned" = "seagreen",
                 "Unburned" = "blue") 
# Initialize ggplot
ggplot(tussocks_clean, aes(x = site, y = average_moss_cm, color = site)) +
  # Raw data points (jittered horizontally)
  geom_jitter( 
    width = 0.2, # Horizontal spread
    height = 0, # No vertical jitter
    shape = 1, # Open circles
    size = 3, #larger than default
    alpha = 0.5, #50% tranparency
    show.legend = FALSE # No legend entry
  ) +
  # Mean points
  stat_summary(
    fun = mean, # Calculate group means
    geom = "point", #Display as points
    size = 4, # Larger than data points
    show.legend = FALSE #No legend entry
  ) +
  # Standard error bars
  stat_summary(
    fun.data = mean_se, # Calculate mean ± standard error
    geom = "errorbar", #Display as error bars
    width = 0.2, #Width of error bar caps
    linewidth = 1, #Thickness of error bars
    show.legend = FALSE #No legend entry
  ) +
  # Apply custom colors
  scale_color_manual(values = site_colors) +
  # Labels and theme
  labs(
    title = "Tussock Height by Site", #Title
    subtitle = "Scott Wagner", #Subtitle label
    x = "Site", #y-axis label
    y = "Tussock Height (cm)" #x-axis label
  ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white"), # plot area white
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"), #background white
    panel.grid = element_blank(), #remove all gridlines
    legend.position = "none",
    #Text formatting
    axis.text = element_text(size = 12, color = "black"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 14),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
  )
